page.title: 07Glapthorn Cow Pasture
page.content: In Glapthorn there is an important nature reserve which is the home of the Black Hair Streak Butterfly. It was first discovered in Britain in 1858 in Kettering and 1859 in Oundle. It is about one inch long (about 3 cms.) and they fly right at the tops of the trees. It only flies the last week of June and the first fortnight of July, the rest of the time it is a caterpiller. The caterpillers eat leaves of young blackthorn. The adults eat the nectar of a plant called privet. The butterflies lay eggs at the Cow Pastures because the conditions in the blackthorn are just right. Glapthorn Cow Pasture is one of the very few places in Britain where the Black Hair Streak Butterfly is found.
